_exec_summary.SummaryText:
GEO SPECIALTY CHEMICALS, INC. - Cedartown, Georgia



INTRODUCTION

The Cedartown plant, owned by GEO Specialty Chemicals, Inc., was built in 1900 and began manufacturing cotton under garments in 1901.  The plant is on a 14 ac. site located approximately 1 mile west of the center of town in Polk county Georgia.  Currently, GEO Specialty Chemicals, Inc. is a global manufacturer of a variety of industrial chemical products, including paints and coating products, water treatment chemicals, consumer additives, custom solutions resin additives, products, polyester liquids, powder resin coatings, and aqueous polyurethane dispersion resins.



1.0 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

GEO has a history of commitment to the town of Cedartown, surrounding community and our employees.  Our commitment is demonstrated in the resources invested in accident prevention such as safety and operations training of our personnel, incident investigations, and standards for design, installation, operations and maintenance of our processes.  The Cedartown facility has 3 major process areas and is operated 24 hr./day 365 days/year.  The facility stores three regulated substances in quantities above the Risk Management Plan [RMP] threshold.  These materials are RMP toxic substances.



2.0 STATIONARY SOURCE & REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

Oleum [CAS# 7446-11-9].  Used in the production of sulfonated naphthalene intermediates; the precursor for all LOMAR products as well as the alkyl sulfonated naphthalene.

Formaldehyde [CAS# 50-00-0].  Used in the condensation reaction step of the LOMAR products and alkyl sulfonated naphthalene.  Smaller quantities are used in other products.

Cyclohexylamine [CAS# 102-71-2].  Used in the neutralization step of certain alkyl naphthalene sulfonates.



3.0 KEY OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS SCENARIOS

EPA's RMP rule requires that we provide information about the worst-case release scenarios and alternative release scenarios for our

facility.  The following are brief summaries of these scenarios:

Worst-case Release Scenario - The catastrophic failure of the largest storage tank with its maximum allowable inventory spilled into a dike under the atmospheric conditions.

Alternative Release Scenario - The rupture of transfer unloading line into the storage tank that would result in the uncontrolled release for 5-min. in unloading area.



4.0 GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM   AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

We take a systematic, proactive approach to prevent accidental releases of hazardous chemicals. Our management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs including:  Process safety information, Process hazard analysis, Operating procedures, Training, Mechanical integrity, Management of change, Pre-startup review, Compliance audits, Incident investigation, Employee participation, Hot work permit and Contractors.  GEO Specialty Chemicals, Inc., is committed to the standard that these management systems set for the way we do business, and we have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that we are meeting our own high standards for accident prevention.



5.0 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

GEO Specialty Chemicals, Inc., keep records for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility.  During the past five years there were no accidental chemical releases involving materials covered under EPA's RMP rule that resulted in injuries, significant property damage, or environmental damage either on site or off site.



6.0 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

GEO Specialty Chemicals, Inc. has a written Emergency Response Plan that addresses the requirements of OSHA and the EPA for the safety and protection of our employees and the community.  We also maintain a spill contingency plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency notification.  Our program provides the essen

tial planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Furthermore, we coordinate our plan with the community emergency response plan.



7.0 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

GEO Specialty Chemicals, Inc. has prioritized its management system to effectively address hazards and potential risks.  The best available technology is continually researched for the best possible solution for spill prevention and mitigation.  The safety of our employees and the local community, in which we work & live, has and continued to be our primary focus.
